content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze the payoff matrix of this game:

|     | R    | B     |
|---|---|-------|
| R  | 45,45 | 0,40  |
| B  | 40,0  | 20,20 |

To maximize my earnings in this game, I would look for a strategy that consistently provides me with a higher payoff. Since the game has 75 rounds, we should consider not only the immediate payoffs but also long-term returns.

In this case, if I pick R and my opponent picks B (the opposite of my choice), I get 0$ in the current round but have the opportunity to earn more in the following rounds since choosing R yields a higher payoff when my opponent chooses B. Conversely, if I pick B and my opponent picks R, I earn 40$ in the current round but have limited opportunities for higher returns due to the lower payoff when my opponent chooses R.

With that in mind, it seems beneficial to pick a strategy that encourages my opponent to choose B more often, as this would lead to me getting a higher payoff in more rounds. One way to do this is to pick R for the first few rounds and then switch strategies based on my opponent's behavior.

However, since we don't know our opponent's strategy, I will make an assumption that they are also rational and will try to maximize their earnings as well. This means they would likely try to exploit any predictable pattern in my choice selections. In this scenario, it could be advantageous to appear unpredictable by varying the choices made across different rounds.

Considering all these factors, I believe that it's beneficial to pick a mix of both R and B, aiming for a somewhat balanced distribution of each choice over the 75 rounds. This strategy may help minimize the chances of my opponent exploiting any predictable pattern in my choices, while still providing an opportunity for higher payoffs when my opponent selects the opposite of what I chose.

In summary, my choice would be to play a mix of both R and B across the 75 rounds, and I'll denote it as {M}. However, keep in mind that the actual outcome could vary depending on the strategy used by my opponent, which is unknown at this point.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, since my opponent has chosen B in the previous round, I will mix things up by choosing R this time. This strategy aims to keep my opponent guessing and minimize any potential exploitation of a predictable pattern in my choices. So my choice for the next round would be {R}.

To maximize my earnings over the long run, it would be advantageous for me to encourage my opponent to continue choosing B so that I can take full advantage of the higher payoff when they do.
